content.html:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson. Double click on mathematical expressions/equations to enlarge.
For questions 1 - 2, simplify each expression using division.

  1. \(\frac{45x^5y^9}{-60x^8y^6}\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 6.3.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(-\frac{3y^3}{4x^3}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \((48y^4-24y^3) \div (-8y^2)\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 6.3.1 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(-6y^2+3y\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

For questions 3–4, divide using long division.

  1. \((m^3+1000) \div (m+10)\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 6.3.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(m^2-10m+100\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \((125y^3-64) \div (5y+4)\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 6.3.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(25y^2-20y+16- \frac{128}{5y+4}\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

For questions 5–6, divide using synthetic division.

  1. \((b^3-3b^2-4b+12) \div (b+2)\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 6.3.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \( b^2-5b+6\); remainder \(0\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \((3x^4-11x^3+2x^2+10x+6) \div (x-3)\)

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 6.3.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(3x^3-2x^2-4x-2\); remainder \(0\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

For questions 7–8, use the following polynomial functions.

  • \(f(x)=x^2-13x+36\)
  • \(g(x)=x-4\)
  1. Find \((\frac{f}{g})(x)\).

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 6.3.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(x-9\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Find \((\frac{f}{g})(-1)\).

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 6.3.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is –10. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Use the Remainder Theorem to find the remainder.

    \(f(x)=x^2-4x-9\) is divided by \(x + 2\)

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 6.3.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 3. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Use the Factor Theorem to determine if \(x-c\) is a factor of the polynomial function.
    Determine whether \(x - 3\) is a factor of \(x^3-7x^2+11x+3\).

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 6.3.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is yes. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?
